description: Such policies may have limited effect or even backfire, resulting in greater market failure
objective: List the drawbacks/limitations of privatisation and deregulation
Question: What are the disadvantages of privatisation and deregulation?
Answer: Even when you break up a monopoly, you may just get oligopolies. However, one still has to consider if that is better than a single monopoly (ie. a second best solution as the ideal of perfect competition is hard to attain).
subject: Economics

description: Minimum wage policy protects the lower income group by making a mandatory minimum wage which employers have to pay their employees
objective: Define, understand, and evaluate minimum wage policies
Question: What is a minimum wage policy?
Answer: A minimum wage policy is a mandatory wage floor that sets the lowest wage an employer can pay
subject: Economics

description: Skills training improves the productivity of workers and allow them to move up the corporate ladder more easily
objective: Define, understand, and evaluate skills training
Question: What is the major disadvantage of training?
Answer: It takes a long time!
subject: Economics

description: Reducing foreign worker permits restricts the supply of labour and thus pushes up wages
objective: Understand and evaluate the regulation of foreign worker permits
Question: What is one effect of introduction of foreign labour?
Answer: Wage levels (especially lower income groups) tend to be depressed.
subject: Economics

description: Income tax is progressive and thus equalises after-tax incomes
objective: Understand and evaluate progressive income tax as a solution for inequality
Question: How can a progressive tax promote equality in wages?
Answer: Progressive tax means that the tax rate increase as the income level increases. This will help to reduce the difference in after-tax incomes. The revenue earned by the government can then be channelled to the poor.
subject: Economics

description: Benefits allow the lower income group to receive subsidies, thus improving their standard of living
objective: Understand and evaluate the benefits system
Question: What are the two kinds of benefits?
Answer: Universal benefits and benefits in kind. They are defined in the checkpoint.
subject: Economics

description: Explain what government failure means
objective: Define government failure
Question: When does government failure happen?
Answer: Government failure is when the government tries to intervene in the market but in the end, the situation is worse off in terms of even lower levels of efficiency or welfare.
subject: Economics

description: Explain the reasons for government failure
objective: Understand the reasons for government failure
Question: Why do governments fail?
Answer: Information, incentives, distribution and time.
subject: Economics

description: Ideally, one should recognise the symetries between KEIs and traditional metrics used in microeconomics
objective: List the different Key Economic Indicators
Question: What are the Four Main KEIs?
Answer: GDP, Inflation Rate, Unemployment Rate, Balance of Payments
subject: Economics

description: Let's start by defining inflation. It is the rate of growth of prices levels.
objective: Define inflation
Question: What is the definition of inflation?
Answer: General rise in the price of level of goods and services over a period of time
subject: Economics

description: One must understand that the CPI is simply of the proxies of inflation; most central banks use what we term "core inflation" which is usually significantly lower than headline inflation.
objective: Understand the construction of the CPI
Question: What are some of the key features in the CPI?
Answer: Price of common household products - rice, chicken etc.
subject: Economics

description: This is usually a 2 mark question in case studies; one must be clear to note that a decreasing inflation rate does not mean there is deflation.
objective: Calculate inflation rate from CPI values given
Question: How does one determine the inflation rate from the Consumer Price Index?
Answer: By observing changes in a weighted index, the percentage increase in the index is equal to the inflation rate for that period
subject: Economics

description: One must realise that the concept of full employment is very subjective; there are many conflicting view points; but generally speaking full employment does not mean that everyone is employed - that is impossible; the natural rate of unemployment is defined as the sum of structural and frictional unemployment
objective: Define and understand the 3 types of unemployment
Question: What are the three kinds of unemployment?
Answer: Cyclical , Structural, Frictional
subject: Economics

description: One must realise the importance of the sticky wage argument which played a vital role in keynes' advocation of fiscal policy
objective: Differentiate between equilibrium and disequilibrium unemployment
Question: Why might wages be sticky downwards? Consider microfoundations of market structure for an answer.
Answer: More hints? Think about what happens when a boss tries to lower someone's wages. Is it difficult to achieve that? Will the worker take that well? Consider outside of Singapore - in many of those countries, unions exist to push up wages regularly. They protest against lowering of wages!
subject: Economics

description: The philips curve is not in the H2 syllabus; but it is rather trivial; it can be derived from AD-AS analysis
objective: Identify the inverse relationship between unemployment and income
Question: How do you derive the philips curve from AD-AS analysis?
Answer: Consider what happens to the General Price Level when AD increases (or conversely).
subject: Economics

description: Demand deficient unemployment is one of the most common forms of unemployment one will encounter in the H2 syllabus; it is important to master this concept well.
objective: Define demand-deficient unemployment
Question: Draw on a labour market diagram. What happens to the labour market when AD falls?
Answer: Your employment level falls!
subject: Economics

description: In Singapore, the main forms of structural unemployment are workers who lack the skills to take up new jobs in high skilled manufacturing industries as low-skilled industries leave the country due to cost concerns.
objective: Define structural unemployment
Question: What causes structural unemployment?
Answer: Mismatch of skills.
subject: Economics

description: Frictional unemployment is generally not a strong concern in singapore given our small size as a country; but with countries such as the US or the UK, geographical constraints may widen the extent of frictional unemployment
objective: Define frictional unemployment

Answer: Consider the causes of frictional unemployment.
subject: Economics

Question: Define GDP
Answer: Market value of all officially recognised final goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time
subject: Economics

objective: Define GNP
Question: What's the difference between GDP and GNP
Answer: GDP looks at the value of goods produced within the boundaries of the country, while GNP looks at the value of goods produced by Singaporeans , both local and foreign.
subject: Economics

Answer: Your trade figures largely decide your current account.

checkpoint: Our Capital Account - An Understanding Of Our Country's Finances
description: In Singapore FDI and financial investments are the main items in the capital account due to our nature as SEA's financial hub
objective: Understand that investment forms the main item in the capital account
Question: What can cause changes in the capital account?
Answer: Changes in ownership of assets causes fluctuations in the capital account. This includes foreign direct investment like buildings or manufacturing plants. This also includes portfolio investment like purchases of shares and bonds.
subject: Economics

objective: Distinguish between different defintions of the items in the BOP
Question: What are the two primary components of your BOP?
Answer: Current and Capital Account. The IMF adds a third "Financial Account", but in convention we usually include it under Capital Account.

description: The idea here is to understand how most questions are structured: most have some sort of preamble about GDP numbers being a proxy for SOL; the obvious thing to do is to bring in non-material factors as proxies for the anti thesis.
objective: Understand that SOL can be measured in terms of material and non material well being
Question: What are the two ways in which Standard of Living can be described by?
Answer: Material and Non-Material Standard of Living
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Welfare Of The Materialistic Person - Material SOL
description: The idea here is to understand that every part of RGDP per capita is important.
objective: Understand that we measure material well being using real GDP per capita
Question: Real GDP per Capita - what is the significance of every word in this term?
Answer: Real implies that inflation has been accounted for. If GDP increases but only nominally (ie. it is all eaten up by inflation and you can only buy the same amount of stuff as before) then you are no better off than you were. GDP implies that your SOL is closely tied to your purchasing power. Indeed, your purchasing power is a good proxy to your SOL. Your healthcare, education, and material well being is closely related to how much money you have. Per capita matters because even if you have a large GDP, having a larger population will dilute the large GDP into very small portions for each person in your country.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: The Long Term View On High Real GDP
description: An increase in real GDP per capita can in fact lead to a decrease in the material SOL in the long run as resources are depleted.
objective: Understand that real GDP per capita is only one of the main proxies with which we use to measure material SOL
Question: There are many other indices we can use to measure standard of living. What are some that you can find?
Answer: We suggest you begin by looking at the Human Development Index. Google it!
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Looking At The Finer Things - Non-Material SOL
description: It is generally not the job of Economics to measure non-material SOL; but nevertheless non-material SOL can be measured using alternative and more holistic indices such as the HDI etc.
objective: Understand that non-material SOL also plays an important part in helping us gauge the overall SOL of a country
Question: Suggest other indicators of non-material SOL.

objective: Understanding that answering the question matters for exams
Question: Remember:
Answer: Always read the question. And read it again (because you are usually wrong the first time).
subject: Economics

description: We always need barometers. In microeconomics we have efficiency. In macroeconomics we have 4 indicators: the inflation rate, the unemployment rate, economic growth, as well as the balance of payments.
objective: List the 4 macroeconomic goals
Question: What are the 4 macroeconomic goals?
Answer: Sustained economic growth, low stable inflation, low unemployment, and external stability.
subject: Economics

description: Let's start with unemployment. What can cause unemployment to change?
objective: Understand causes of unemployment
Question: What causes unemployment?
Answer: Demand deficient (cyclical) unemployment and structural unemployment are only two ways that cause unemployment.
subject: Economics

description: So what's so bad about unemployment? You can just go take a holiday right? That's if you can even afford it. But there are worse things than not getting an income during unemployment. First, let's look at resources.
objective: Understand that unemployment is bad because resources are being underutilised.
Question: In turn, why is the underutilisation of resources bad?
Answer: The opportunity cost of lost production are permanent! It cannot simply be reclaimed (unless you have a time machine of course).
subject: Economics

description: Second, when workers stop working for too long, they lose their skills and gradually exit the labour force. Their skills turn rusty as well.
objective: Understand that unemployment is bad because workers tend to lose their skills
Question: What happens to workers after prolonged periods of unemployment?
Answer: They lose their skills, become disenchanted, and exit the labour force.
subject: Economics

description: Third, if people don't work, they don't earn income. They can't pay taxes and the government loses out on tax revenue.
objective: Understand that unemployment is bad because it lowers tax revenue
Question: If workers cannot earn income, what happens to tax revenue?
Answer: It drops because without income, there'd be no income tax receipts.
subject: Economics

description: Let's move on to inflation. First, let's see what causes inflation.
objective: Understand that interaction between the AD and AS causes inflation.
Question: Interaction of the Aggregate Demand and Aggregate Supply (you'll learn those in a while. For now, think of them as demand and supply for the entire economy) contributes to inflation. Hence inflation can be caused by either...
Answer: AD (demand side) or AS (supply side).
subject: Economics

description: So what's bad about inflation? First, it erodes the export competitiveness of the country that experiences high inflation.
objective: Understand that high inflation erodes export competitiveness
Question: How can high inflation adversely affect countries?
Answer: When relative inflation rates in a country are higher than those of exporting partners, exports become relative more expensive and imports become relatively cheaper; this may lead to a worsening trade position, which can lead to a fall in NY.
subject: Economics

description: Second, erratic inflation confuses people. It confuses producers too. Let's see what that implies.
objective: Understand that highly erratic inflation causes allocative inefficiency.
Question: How can fluctuating inflation adversely affect countries?
Answer: Producers may perceive changes in price levels and changes in demand. This may lead them to over or under produce, causing allocative inefficiency.
subject: Economics

description: If you are a restaurant owner and inflation changes prices all the time, you have to print your menu every week! That may incur small printing costs because you only operate a sushi bar, but what if you're a large producer (like IKEA) that maintains a huge range of products? That will be a significant cost.
objective: Understand that highly erratic inflation causes producers to incur menu costs.
Question: How can fluctuating inflation affect menu costs?
Answer: It increases menu costs because producers have to change their prices often.
subject: Economics

description: Let's move on to economic growth. We can distinguish between the two types of economic growth - actual and potential.
objective: Distinguish between actual and potential growth
Question: What are the two types of economic growth?
Answer: Actual economic growth represents the fact that there is an actual increase in output; whereas potential economic growth represents an increase in the productive capacity of the economy.
subject: Economics

description: Let's look at the first type of economic growth - actual growth. Why is actual growth important?
objective: Understand the importance of actual economic growth
Question: Why is actual economic growth important?
Answer: It gives consumers more purchasing power (to buy more things. And more things are usually good!) It also allows more people to be employed, preventing all the bad things about unemployment from happening. Do you still remember what those are?
subject: Economics

description: Time for the second type of economic gowth - potential growth. Why is potential growth important?
objective: Understand the importance of potential economic growth
Question: Why is potential economic growth important?
Answer: Imagine pouring water into a bottle. If the bottle doesn't become bigger and water keeps flowing in, eventually it will overflow. In economics, the water is actual growth. The bottle is economic potential. Inflation happens when the water overflows (trying to fit too much water in a small bottle). Potential growth makes the bottle bigger, allowing more water to flow in. In economic terms, it prevents the economy from overheating.
subject: Economics

description: We move to Balance of Payments. Two scenarios can occur for balance of payments - deficit and surplus.
objective: Understand that BOP surplus is usually preferable to BOP deficit
Question: Which is preferable? BOP surplus or deficit?
Answer: Usually the surplus. Problems associated with the deficit are much more severe.
subject: Economics

description: Let's see why the balance of payment deficit can bad thing.
objective: Understand how BOP deficits can be bad for the economy
Question: How can BOP deficits be bad for an ecoomy?
Answer: It can cause imported inflation. Underlying a BOP deficit can be a trade problem. Finally, it will deplete one's foreign reserves. However, a BOP deficit may not always be bad, especially when a country is investing overseas, hence making a loss in the short run (and profiting in the long run).
subject: Economics

description: Let's see why the balance of payment surplus can be a bad thing too.
objective: Understand how BOP surpluses can be bad for the economy
Question: How can BOP surpluses be bad for an economy?
Answer: It leads to the appreciation of a country's exchange rate, eroding export competitiveness by making exports more expensive. It may also represent a short term inflow of money which may indicate speculative attack.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: The Multiplier In The Real World
description: What is the big deal with the multiplier anyway?
objective: Understand the importance of the multiplier in the real world
Question: What is the big deal with the multiplier anyway?
Answer: The multiplier is the cornerstone of Keynesian economics, but it also has several limitations depending on the nature of the economy in question.
topic: National Income, Aggregate Demand and Supply, National Expenditure
subject: Economics

description: Fiscal Policy is a really important policy that you will come across in Macroeconomics; master it well.
objective: Identify the role that Fiscal Policy plays in the entire Macroeconomic Framework
Question: What is fiscal policy?
Answer: Fiscal policy is the deliberate manipulation of government spending and taxation to achieve the 4 main macroeconomic goals.
subject: Economics

description: The main treatment of Fiscal Policy usually deals with deliberate government spending, but it is important to be introduced to alternative, and often less common forms of Fiscal Policy
objective: Distinguish between progressive and regressive tax rates as well as distinguish the two kinds of fiscal policy
Question: A decrease in capital gains tax is introduced to stimulate investment; is it regressive or progressive? Why?
Answer: Consider the propensity for rich or poor individuals to engage in private investment (bonds etc)
subject: Economics

description: Before one can evaluate Fiscal Policies, one must understand the composition of the government budget -- And, notably, which plays a larger part.
objective: Understand the composition of the government budget
Question: What are the two components of the governemt budget?
Answer: Simple! Spending (outflow) and taxation receipts (inflow).
subject: Economics

description: It is important to clarify any misconceptions of what are injections and what are withdrawals in the circular flow of income; Private consumption and savings are within the circular flow whereas all other variables G,T,I,(X-M) are outside the circular flow and thus contribute to injections and withdrawals
objective: Recognise that government spending and taxation are outside the circular flow of income
Question: Does the level of income change government spending?
Answer: No! They are autonomous (ie. the level of income does not change government spending). This is unlike consumption which is dependent on income.
subject: Economics

description: While the multiplier effect is often a key argument for the implementation of fiscal policy; one must recognise that not all subscribe to the Keynesian view of Economics (see neoclassical arguments and expectations-augmented phillips curve)
objective: Understand the underpinnings of Fiscal Policy and why the multiplier effect is such an important concept that is used to legitimise Fiscal Policy (from a Keynesian point of view)
Question: In short, what is the multiplier effect?
Answer: It is the idea that one person's spending is another's income, and hence an increase in income has a more than proportionate effect on national output.
subject: Economics

description: Often, in examinations, one is expected to provide a numerical (as well as an explanation in prose) of the multiplier process. This is important to demonstrate to the reader that you have understood the material.
objective: Understand how to use a numerical example of the multiplier.
Question: The MPC in Singapore is 0.1. The government makes an autonomous increase of government spending by 10m. State the net increase in NY. Show numerical explanation, and state your assumptions.
Answer: Consider the formula of the multiplier, and note that the MPC excludes information about MPT and (X-M).
subject: Economics

description: It is important to the understand the policy implications of changes in G vs changes in T
objective: Distinguish between changes in G and T
Question: The MPC in Singapore is 0.1. The government makes an autonomous increase of government taxation by 10m. State the net decrease in NY. Show numerical explanation, and state your assumptions.
Answer: Consider the formula of the multiplier, and note that the MPC excludes information about MPT and (X-M).
subject: Economics

description: One should recognise that the integrity of the sticky wage argument usually holds true in areas where the labour market does not clear; and also, that making labour markets more efficient (as in the introduction of a variable wage component) is an important policy outcome
objective: Understand the sticky wage argument and why Keynes argued for Fiscal Policy
Question: Does sticky wages make unemployment worse?
Answer: It does! Since wages do not drop in tandem with demand, there will be disequilibrium unemployment.
subject: Economics

description: This portion of the lecture is mainly about how you should present your answer in the exam.
objective: Show how Fiscal Policy can be used in recessions using a numerical example accompanied with an explanation.
Question: During a recession, do we use expansionary of contractionary fiscal policy?
Answer: Expansionary. One should increase government spending or decrease taxation (or do both) to increase AD, and through the multiplier effect increase national output by a larger than proportionate amount.
subject: Economics

description: You have learnt that Fiscal Policy is often used in recessions; but most do not recognise its uses in achieving other Macroeconomic goals
objective: Understand that Fiscal Policy plays a role in stabilising inflation
Question: How can fiscal policy stabilise inflation?
Answer: It can cool down the economy by lowering AD (through decreasing G or increasing T), hence reducing the demand for produce in the economy and pulling down the price level.
subject: Economics

description: It is important at this point to start being able to draw links between Fiscal Policy and other parts of Macroeconomics and seeing how they link together.
objective: Demonstrate how Fiscal Policy can be used to curb deflation; and briefly establish the negative effects of deflation
Question: Show using a diagram and explanation how Fiscal Policy can curb deflation. What policy options are available?
Answer: One can choose to adopt expansionary fiscal policy! This involves increasing G or decreasing T.
subject: Economics

description: Recognise that there is a paradoxical relationship between achieving low inflation and economic growth (see philips curves); recognise that supply-side policies often come into play for long run economic growth, and that fiscal policy used to curb deflation is often an extreme measure only used in desperate situations (see oil embargo crisis)
objective: Demonstrate how Fiscal Policy can be used to curb inflation; and briefly establish the negative effects of inflation
Question: Show using a diagram and explanation how Fiscal Policy can curb inflation. What policy options are available?
Answer: One can choose to adopt contractionary fiscal policy! This involves decreasing G or increasing T.
subject: Economics

description: You have just learnt that Fiscal Policy can help curb inflation; now draw links to inflation and a healthy BOP for yourself and think about how Fiscal Policy can come into play before watching this video.
objective: Understand how Fiscal Policy can help to correct BOP deficits
Question: A country is experiencing relatively higher inflation rates than its trading partners; Describe and explain the effect of this on the BOP. State your assumptions.
Answer: What is the compositions of the BOP?
subject: Economics

description: Again, one must recognise the paradoxical relationship between a contractionary fiscal policy and achieving higher (X-M). The optimal trade-off is a difficult question to answer ( can be answered using indifference analysis which is beyond the scope of our discussion)
objective: Use the AD/AS framework to show how Fiscal Policy can help to address relatively high inflation rates.
Question: How is there a paradoxical relationship between contractionary fiscal policy and achieving higher (X-M)?
Answer: In order to achieve higher net exports, we want to allow our currency to depreciate. This involves lowering inflation relative to other countries. This involves contractionary fiscal policy. However, contractionary policy causes AD to go down (in contrary to what we are trying to achieve with higher net exports). Hence there's a paradox here. Eventually it depends on which of the two (net exports or G/T) exerts a larger effect on AD.
subject: Economics

description: So far, you have learnt how Fiscal Policy can be used in various situations; however, to demonstrate a true understanding of Fiscal Policy and to show you have thought about what you have learnt, you will need to be able to evaluate Fiscal Policy
objective: Recognise that the crowding out effect is an important consideration in whether to use Fiscal Policy
Question: How does government spending crowd out investment?
Answer: Excessive government spending forces the government to borrow money to fund its deficits. This increases the market interest rate, forcing investment down. For more information, look into monetary policy and the Marginal Efficiency of Investment.
subject: Economics

description: One must be cognisant of the fact that the size of the multiplier is contingent on geographic considerations; and hence, whether or not Fiscal Policy should be implemented (or how successful it may be) will vary from country to country
objective: recognise that the size of the multiplier is an important consideration in whether to use Fiscal Policy
Question: Consider a country with an MPM of 0.1 vs another with an MPM of 0.2. Which is more likely to implement Fiscal Policy? Why? State your assumptions.
Answer: Consider the role that imports play in the circular flow, are they a form of injections of withdrawals? what is the implication of your answer?
subject: Economics

description: Let's start with interest rates. Interest rates can be thought of as one's compensation for parting with one's money.
objective: Define interest rate as compensation for parting with money
Question: What is one definition of interest rate?
Answer: If I lend you money in 2011, you will return me that sum in 2015 plus an additional amount of money as compensation because I will need to be compensated for not having the money for 5 years. What is that extra sum called?
subject: Economics

checkpoint: A More Interesting Definition Of Interest Rate
description: Great! You know that interest is a lender's compensation. Now let's look at this scenario from the borrower's perspective. Then, interest, to the borrower, is the price of borrowing money.
objective: Define interest rate as the price of borrowing money.
Question: What is another way to look at interest rates?
Answer: If you borrow money from me and have to incur $500 dollars of interest, can that $500 be considered a price? If so, what item is the price for?
subject: Economics

description: Now let's talk about the demand and supply of money. We will begin with the demand of money first.
objective: Define the demand for money
Question: What are the two factors that influence the demand of money?
Answer: Transaction and asset motives!
subject: Economics

description: Now that we have talked about demand, let's explore the supply of money in an economy!
objective: Define the supply for money
Question: Who decides the supply of money in an economy?
Answer: The central bank.
subject: Economics

description: We have demand and we have supply. Now let's put those two together to get the short term interest rate.
objective: Define short term interest rate
Question: How is the short term interest rate determined?
Answer: By the intesection of the money demand and the money supply.
subject: Economics

description: Now that we know what short term interest rate is, let's explore a more fundamental concept - long term interest rate. Instead of being determined by the demand and supply of money, it is determined by economic fundamentals,
objective: Define long term interest rate
Question: How is the long term interest rate determined?
Answer: By economic fundamentals.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Difference Between Long Term And Short Term Interest Rate
description: Now let's try and differentiate the two concepts lest we confuse them. Short run interest rate always tends towards the long run interest rate in longer periods.
objective: Differentiate long term and short term interest rate
Question: What does the short run interest rate tend to in the long run?
Answer: The long run interest rate.
subject: Economics

description: Now different economists interpret the increase or decrease in money supply differently. All these hinges on their interpretation of price flexibility. Let's listen to the old school first, or what we call classical economists.
objective: Understand how Classical economists interprete money given complete flexibility in prices
Question: What happens when prices are flexible and money supply is increased?
Answer: When money supply increases, interest rates drop first. However, the increase in money supply cuases prices to increase since prices are flexible. The inflation causes increase in demand for money because prices are simply higher. This increase in demand offsets the initial drop in interest rates, bringing interest rates back to their original level.
subject: Economics

description: Economists then caught up with reality (surprise surprise). Keynesian economists realised that prices are actually sticky in the short run. This postulation has great impacts on interest rates and money supply.
objective: Understand how Keynesians interepete money given sticky prices.
Question: What happens when prices are sticky and money supply is increased?
Answer: When money supply increases, interest rates drop first. Increase in money supply does not cause prices to increase because prices are sticky in the short run. This causes a drop in short term interest rates. However, in the long run, prices are flexible again. Hence, inflation happens and demand for money increases. This offsets the original drop in interest rate, causing short term interest rates to approximate long run interest rates.
subject: Economics

description: So we have two interpretations here. Which interpretation do we adopt? Turns out the Keynesian one is a more accurate depiction of reality and that is the one we choose to stick with.
objective: Understand that sticky prices in the Short Run is a better reflection of the real world
Question: Is there price stickiness in the short run? What about in the long run. Which interpretation is this?
Answer: Price stickiness happens in the short run. However, in the long run, prices are no longer sticky. This is the Keynesian interpretation.
subject: Economics

description: Now let's go into monetary policy proper. Monetary policy is defined as the deliberate manipulation of interest rates to achieve macroeconomic goals. The government achieves that through manipulating the money supply.
objective: Define monetary policy
Question: Can you arbitrarily choose both the interest rate and the money supply?
Answer: No. When you choose one, the other is decided by the money demand.
subject: Economics

description: To understand the effects of monetary policy on economic growth, let's break down economic growth into its substituent components. First, we look at consumption.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on domestic consumption
Question: What type of goods are most influenced by interest rate changes?
Answer: Durables! Because they usually take up a large proportion of your income. Then, interest rate fluctuations have significant impacts.
subject: Economics

description: Now that we have dealt with consumption, we look at investment next. Loosely, investment is related to interest rate due to the profitability of projects. More formally, we define this using the Marginal Efficiency of Investment or the MEI.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on investment
Question: If interest rate goes up, what happens to investment?
Answer: When interest rate goes up, the number of profitable projects that can achieve a rate of return more than or equal to the interest rate decreases. This can be shown in the MEI. when that happens, the amount of investment decreases.
subject: Economics

description: We have covered consumption and investment. Government spending naturally comes next. Interest rates are related to government spending through the cost of borrowing.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on government spending
Question: What happens to the cost of borrowing and hence government spending when interest rate goes down?
Answer: When interest rate goes down, the cost of borrowing decreases. Governments will find it cheaper to finance a deficit. That increases the incentive of deficit spending, hence governments may spend more.
subject: Economics

description: After consumption, investment and government spending, net exports naturally come next. The effects on net exports are due to the influence of interest rate on exchange rates. Note that only relative (not absolute) interest rates are used here.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on net exports
Question: Let's say country A increased its interest rates. What happens?
Answer: Maybe nothing! That depends on the interest rate of country A relative to its trading partners. If country A increases its interest rate, but so does country B C D and everyone else, then nothing will happen. However, if country A's interest rate happens to be higher than those of its trading partners, then there will be hot money inflow. Country A's currency will appreciate against other currencies. In that case, its net exports will decrease
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Cookies, Cars, Factories And What Not
description: Now that we have covered all the components of Aggregate Demand, let's look at what happens to overall economic growth.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on overall economic growth
Question: When I lower interest rates, what happens to economic growth?
Answer: Lowering of interest rate is expansionary monetary policy. AD increases and national income increases more than proportionately due to the multiplier. Hence, there is actual economic growth. However, potential economic growth is minimal.
subject: Economics

description: Having covered economic growth, let's move on to unemployment. Unemployment changes inversely with economic growth. However, what type of unemployment is affected?
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on unemployment levels
Question: What type of unemployment does monetary policy solve?
Answer: Cyclical unemployment.
subject: Economics

description: We move on to the next macroeconomic goal. The effects of monetary policy on inflation depends on the region of the AS that the AD lies in.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on price levels and inflation
Question: If the AD lies in the Keynesian region and expansionary monetary policy is used, will there be inflation?
Answer: No there won't be because the AS is flat in that region.
subject: Economics

description: The last macroeconomic goal is external balance. Monetary policy has effects on external balance as well because it influence the current account.
objective: Understand the impact of monetary policy on external balance
Question: Again, are we interested in the absolute or the relative interest rate here?
Answer: Relative! What matters is your interest rate level compared to those of other countries.
subject: Economics

description: Now let's start evaluating the usefulness of monetary policy. First, monetary policy depends on the sentiments of consumers and investors!
objective: Evaluate monetary policy using sentiments
Question: If sentiments are very depressed, what happens to the MEI?
Answer: The MEI becomes rather steep and unresponsive to interest rate changes.
subject: Economics

description: The second evaluation we can have is the liquidity trap. This is caused by the shape of the demand curve.
objective: Evaluate monetary policy using the liquidity trap
Question: What happens when you try to do expansionary monetary policy in a liquidity trap?
Answer: The interest rate simply does not increase and the policy will not work!
subject: Economics

description: Third, we evaluate monetary policy using the criterion of specificity. The question we are asking here is: does monetary policy actually solve the underlying problem or does it target something else entirely?
objective: Evaluate monetary policy using the specificity argument
Question: Can monetary policy solve structural unemployment?
Answer: Monetary policy is a demand side policy tool, hence it cannot deal with supply side issues like structural unemployment. Simply put, monetary policy does not impart workers with the skills required to solve structural unemployment.
subject: Economics

description: Finally, we evaluate how price flexibility can influence the effectiveness of monetary policy.
objective: Discuss the impact of price stickiness on monetary policy
Question: If prices are sticky, is monetary policy effective in the short run?
Answer: Yes it is. However, in the long run, price levels are flexible and changes in interest rate will be eroded by changes in the money demand curve.
subject: Economics

description: So does Singapore employ monetary policy? Turns out that the answer is no. This is because Singapore is a small and open country, and we cannot sustain large inflow and outflow of hot money.
objective: Understand why Singapore does not use monetary policy
Question: When large inflow and outflow of hot money happens, what happens to the exchange rate?
Answer: The exchange rate fluctuates rapidly, causing export and import prices to be unstable. This is damaging for an export and import oriented country like Singapore.
subject: Economics

description: Can you have a fixed exchange rate policy, monetary policy, and free flow of capital at the same time? The impossible trinity helps you understand this trilemma.
objective: Understand the impossible trinity
Question: What are the three policy options that you cannot have at the same time?
Answer: A fixed exchange rate, automonous control over interest rate, and free flow of capital in and out of a country's borders.
subject: Economics

description: It will be interesting to understand how money supply is controlled by the government. Here, we describe the three mechanisms through which money supply is controlled.
objective: Explain how money supply is manipulated in detail by the government
Question: What are the three methods that a central bank uses to control money supply?
Answer: Open market operations, reserve ratios, and printing of money.
subject: Economics

description: Exam definition of exchange rate and how exchange rate equilibrium is determined using a graphical illustration.
objective: Define the exchange rate and represent it graphically
Question: What is the definition of exchange rate?
Answer: Exchange rate is the value of one countryâ€™s currency in terms of another currency.
subject: Economics

description: Explains what the demand curve in the forex market represents and what factors cause it to shift.
objective: Describe the factors that constitute the demand for a countryâ€™s currency
Question: What affects the demand for a currency?
Answer: The demand for currency is a derived demand, and thus is determined by the factors that affect the demand for the goods and services they are used to purchase.
subject: Economics

description: Explains what the supply curve in the forex market represents and what factors cause it to shift.
objective: Describe the factors that affect the supply of a countryâ€™s currency
Question: What affects the supply of a currency?
Answer: When you import goods and services, you sell off your domestic currency to purchase them. In doing so, you contribute to the supply of your domestic currency in the forex market.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Exchange Rate Determination In The Long Run
description: Describes how relative price levels of similar goods, relative rates of productivity growth and preferences for imports/exports affect exchange rate in the long run.
objective: List the main factors that determine a countryâ€™s exchange rate in the long term
Question: What factors affect the relative exchange rates of different currencies in the long run?
Answer: Ex/r determination in the long run depends mainly on the relative price levels of similar goods between countries, relative rates of productivity growth, and preferences for certain goods.
subject: Economics

description: Defines the various models of exchange rate systems, and their differences.
objective: Describe the difference between floating, fixed and managed float exchange rate systems
Question: How many different systems to manage exchange rates are there?
Answer: There are mainly three models: a fixed, managed float, and free float exchange rate systems.
subject: Economics

description: Shows adjustment process for a maintaining a fixed exchange rate, and evaluates its effectiveness.
objective: Understand how a fixed exchange rate is maintained, and its pros/cons
Question: How is a fixed exchange rate maintained?
Answer: It is maintained through the buying or selling of the particular currency by the government to offset free market forces.
subject: Economics

description: Describes, using Singapore as an example, how the managed float is utilised and why it is used.
objective: Understand the pros/cons of a managed float system
Question: Why does our government use a managed float system?
Answer: The main reason is that it allows for rapid adjustments in the short term whilst still allowing MAS to set long term goals.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Devaluation Of Currency To Correct A BOP Deficit
description: Assuming PED of both exports and imports are elastic, how does devaluating a currency affect import expenditure/export revenue?
objective: Explain how exchange rate policy is used to ensure balance of payments
Question: What happens to the BOP when you devalue a currency?
Answer: If the PED for exports and imports are both elastic, this will lead to an improvement in the BOP.
lesson: Exchange Rate and The Balance of Payments
subject: Economics

description: Defines M-L condition and explains how it alters the impact a fall in the external value of a currency has on a countryâ€™s BOP
objective: Explain the importance of the M-L condition in assessing the impact of exchange rate policy on BOP
Question: What if the PED for exports and imports are not both elastic? When can we use exchange rate policy to improve the BOP?
Answer: So long as the Marshall-Lerner condition holds, a devaluation of oneâ€™s currency will lead to an improvement in the BOP.
lesson: Exchange Rate and The Balance of Payments
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Limitations Of Using Exchange Rate Policy For BOP
description: What are the problems specific to using exchange rate to correct BOP disequilibrium?
objective: Understand J-curve effect and other evaluations for the effectiveness of using exchange rate policy for BOP goals
Question: What are the problems specific to using exchange rate to correct BOP disequilibrium?
Answer: The problems are mainly the J-curve effect in the short run.
lesson: Exchange Rate and The Balance of Payments
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Objectives Of Exchange Rate Policy In Singapore
description: Describes how maintaining price stability is the main goal Singapore hopes to achieve using exchange rate policy
objective: Understand the main goals Singapore targets through exchange rate policy
Question: What is the main aim of the governmentâ€™s exchange rate policy?
Answer: Exchange rate policy in Singapore is mainly used to achieve price stability.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Exchange Rate Policy Instead Of Monetary Policy
description: Explains how the nature of our economy (small & open), as well as the Open Economy Trilemma, limits us to exchange rate policy.
objective: Understand why Singapore uses this special form of monetary policy
Question: Why do we use exchange rate policy instead of traditional monetary policy?
Answer: This is due to the Open Economy Trilemma and other factors that make exchange rate policy more effective than traditional monetary policy.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: S$NEER (No It's Not Money Sneering At You)
description: What exactly is this awful sounding thing and why do we use it?
objective: Describe how the MAS uses S$NEER to manage the exchange rate in Singapore
Question: What exactly is this awful sounding thing and why do we use it?
Answer: The value of the S$ against this trade-weighted basket of currencies, with the effects of inflation not eliminated, is known as S$NEER.
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Role Of Exchange Rate Policy In Managing Inflation
description: This part explains how exactly Singapore uses exchange rate policy to achieve its main goal of low and stable inflation
objective: Describe how exchange rate affects inflation through import and export prices.
Question: How is exchange rate used to stabilise the GPL?
Answer: Exchange rate policy affects the GPL through two mechanisms that work through import and export prices respectively.
subject: Economics

description: Describes time lags, conflict with other macroeconomic goals and availability of reserves as the main limitations of exchange rate policy. Also explains how monetary policy does not work alone using the Tinbergen-Theil principle.
objective: Understand the main limitations of exchange rate policy
Question: Is exchange rate policy perfect?
Answer: No, nothing is. Ex/r policy is limited by its time lag issues, the potential to conflict with other marcoeconomic goals, as well as the size of a nationâ€™s foreign reserves.
subject: Economics

description: To distinguish supply side policy as a separate class of government policy
objective: Define supply side policy and describe why governments choose to implement supply side policy
Question: Is government expenditure on infrastructure (e.g. roads) considered supply side policy?
Answer: Government expenditure is traditionally classified as fiscal policy, although some forms of government expenditure (e.g. on infrastructure like roads) have secondary supply side effects. Do note that not all government expenditure has supply side effects
subject: Economics

description: Policies within this category are pro-competition policies
objective: Describe and explain the characteristics of policies for product markets
Question: Why is competition amongst firms desirable?
Answer: Reduces productive and allocative inefficiency
subject: Economics

description: Privatisation takes advantage of the profit maximising motive to reduce inefficiency
objective: Explain what privatisation is and how it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why advantage does the private sector have over the public sector?
Answer: Less inefficiency
subject: Economics

description: Deregulation makes it easier for firms to set up business, while competition policies prevent firms from gaining excessive monopoly power
objective: Explain what deregulation and competition policies are and how they work as supply-side policies
Question: How does deregulation and competition work?
Answer: They work by breaking down competition!
subject: Economics

description: SMEs are firms with a relatively small annual revenue and employee size
objective: Explain what SMEs are and how it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why are SMEs important?
Answer: They drive innovation. By allowing more firms to join the economy, the potential of the economy grows.
subject: Economics

description: Policies within this category aim to keep wages reasonable and provide incentives for people to work
objective: Describe and explain the characteristics of policies for the labour market
Question: How will the quantity and quality of the labour force affect aggregate supply?
Answer: Quantity increases productive capacity (i.e. more factor of production), quality reduces cost of production
subject: Economics

checkpoint: Reducing The Power Of Trade Unions
description: Trade unions represent groups within the labour force (e.g. by industry)
objective: Explain what trade unions are and how reducing their power works as a supply-side policy
Question: What is the motive of trade unions?
Answer: Protect the interests of workers in the union by pushing for wage increments and better working conditions
subject: Economics

description: Income policy helps to keep income in line with labour productivity
objective: Explain what income policy is and how it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why is it important to keep wages affordable for employers?
Answer: To prevent excessive lay-offs of workers
subject: Economics

description: Tax reform policy increases the incentive for work effort
objective: Explain what tax reform policy is and how it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why will lowering tax be effective in attracting firms and foreign talent?
Answer: Think why people grumble every time taxes are raised!
subject: Economics

description: Cutting social and welfare programmes will force more people into the workforce
objective: Explain what social and welfare programmes are and how reducing their them works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why will reducing welfare encourage people to work?
Answer: Think about what happened to people in welfare states in Europe!
subject: Economics

description: Interventionist measures are needed when market forces are unlikely to allocate resources appropriately
objective: Distinguish between market oriented and interventionist policies
Question: What situations would market oriented policies be less effective than interventionist measures?
Answer: When there are externalities
subject: Economics

description: Education and skills training increases the quality of the workforce
objective: Explain what education and skills training are and how they work as a supply-side policy
Question: Why is the quality of the workforce important?
Answer: To make up for the low labour supply and to move up the value added production chain
subject: Economics

description: Nationalisation provides government funding for investment in strategic industries
objective: Explain what nationalisation is and how it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Which industries will nationalisation be preferred over privatisation?
Answer: Industries which require heavy investment or industries providing essential services
subject: Economics

description: R&D promotes technological advancement which improves labour productivity
objective: Explain what R&D is and how providing grants for it works as a supply-side policy
Question: Why is there a need to provide grants for R&D?
Answer: R&D can be expensive with uncertain results (i.e. may not yield new technology)
subject: Economics

description: Supply side policies can affect the 4 macroaims of an economy
objective: Describe the effects of supply side policies on the economy
Question: What is the main advantage of supply-side policies over demand management policies?
Answer: Conflict of macroeconomic aims
subject: Economics

description: Like all government policies, there are limits as to what supply side policies can achieve
objective: Explain the limitations of supply side policies
Question: Why is it impractical to use supply-side policies all the time?
Answer: Think what is needed for actual growth and also the time involved
subject: Economics

checkpoint: It's A Small World After All
description: Here you will find out what globalisation really means in economics, beyond catchphrases like â€œThe World is Flatâ€ù.
objective: Define Globalisation
Question: What are the 3 main flows across country borders that increase due to globalisation?
Answer: 1) Trade, 2)Labour and 3) Investment (or Capital)
subject: Economics

description: How to account for the trend towards globalisation, as defined in the previous checkpoint? Letâ€™s find out.
objective: Explore some of the factors that led to globalisation
Question: What do you think are the 3 most important reasons for globalisation in the second half of the 20th century?
Answer: They are those factors we covered in 1.2: Shift in ideology, Awareness of the gains from trade and Technological progress.
subject: Economics

description: You didnâ€™t seriously think that all phenomena under the umbrella called globalisation could be explained by those 3 reasons in the previous checkpoint, did you? Right, knew you were better than that.
objective: Learn how to answer slightly different questions on the trend towards globalisation
Question: How do you answer questions on the reasons for globalisation?
Answer: By assessing the particular context of the question and coming up with reasonable points, supported by economic framework.
subject: Economics

description: Can you explain the impact of globalisation in the systematic way? Here we examine some of the yardsticks we should use.
objective: Assess the impact of globalisation in terms of the 4 macroeconomic aims
Question: What kind of unemployment can globalisation cause?
Answer: In particular, structural unemployment. (Cyclical unemployment, owing to world business cycles also plausibleâ€”though not as specific to the context of globalisation)
subject: Economics

description: Globalisation has microeconomic repercussions too.

Answer: 1. It shows that you have considered the other sides of the issue. 2. You can expose and attack your opponent's arguments, making yours stronger. Win!
subject: General Paper

description: There are always two sides to the big picture. Show the other side.
objective: Craft and attack significant counterarguments in your essay
Question: Here's a little exercise. "It is possible to eradicate poverty." a) Pick a side. b) Pick a significant argument on the other side. c) Attempt writing a counterargument, and rebut it, bearing in mind what you learnt.
Answer: Things to take note of: a) Is your counterargument a strong one? Or is it a minor point? b) Did you manage to show that your side is superior in the end? Or did you just stop at showing the other side?
subject: General Paper

description: It's not shooting yourself in the foot, it's helping to nuance your argument.
objective: How attacking your own point actually strengthens your argument
Question: Using the XYXY... structure, build up a strong argument from the following point. "Poverty is a relative concept, and relative to the population, there will always be people in the bottom percentile who will be deemed poor."
Answer: Think of what others might say to shoot your point down, and then shoot what they will say down.
subject: General Paper

description: Strawmen are weak and attacking weak things doesn't say anything about your skill. Note: In the application question, if you could identify the writer using the strawman fallacy, pointing it out will gain you brownie points.
objective: What the strawman fallacy is, and why you should avoid it
Question: Why is this a strawman fallacy? "Sometimes, the poor are not willing to receive help from others. These people are reluctant to help themselves, so without the motivation to do so, poverty cannot be eradicated from society."
Answer: Are the poor in both sentences referring to the same group of people?
